text: [Music]
welcome to go to Berlin I'm standing
here with Linda Rising what are you
currently working on I'm here at the
goto Berlin Conference and I gave the
morning keynote this morning and it has
to do with an area that I think is
important which is how we make decisions
and in particular this talk Focus
focused on how we make decisions about
who we trust why is trust so important
or why is the keynote about trust so
important for tech people well one of
the things that we know is that we
constantly judge other people as soon as
we meet somebody when we hear for
instance that they're from the United
States we wonder since there was an
election recently we wonder did they
vote for that candidate or the other
candidate so that as soon as we find out
that information we can classify them
and put them in a box and put a label on
it so we all do that all the time and
what we know is that that label for that
person gets in the way of our
interaction with that person and in
particular on a technical team if we
think for instance that someone is not
smart or not able to do the job we don't
have any uh respect for their abilities
that they will know that they will sense
that and that in a way we make them less
capable we make them stupid now if
everybody does that and if everybody is
doing that all the time it's going to
have a major impact on what that team
can produce if we all believe we're
wonderful and if we all believe we're
the most intelligent team
ever then we're going to strive to meet
that expectations I mean stereotyping
just means that you're making your own
judgment about another person it can be
a negative stereotype or a positive
stereotype and as to what you can do
about it the answer is nothing because
we do it that's one of our hardwired
Tendencies we can be aware that we do it
and question those stereotypes if you've
evaluated somebody's performance to say
I don't think they are a good member of
the team you might question that how did
I make that decision how did I reach the
conclusion that this person is not
capable of doing his job or her job so
questioning your evaluation standing
back and trying to be as objective as
possible is one way of trying to get
past it but it there isn't anything you
can do about a cognitive bias so one of
the strongest for instance is the
confirmation bias and that plays a part
in stereotyping and the confirmation
bias prevents us from even seeing any
information that would go against the
decision that we've already made the
confirmation bias is one of our
strongest and it keeps us from wavering
once we made a decision then usually we
only can see hear read appreciate be
open to
information that confirms what we
already believe okay thank you very much
my pleasure
